messages: 7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (23:56): is there anyone here from disqus?
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:08): if i set event handler, then the handler function's 'this' will refer to event caller?
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (00:08): i see one of them now
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:11): 4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049: I talked to anton as he had to leave, so I just sent him an email :-), thank you anyways!
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:12): 30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2: are you using any libraries to normalize the event object accross browsers?!
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:12): if so, whithin the handler this will be the same as event.target
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:13): (this might be specific to jQuery)
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:13): i have rather specific problem, but not related to jQuery, just plain javascript
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:13): 30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2: have you tryed to console.log the this to see its value?
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:14): sec, i already asked in #javascript some time ago

30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:15): MyClass.prototype.f = function() {}; MyClass.prototype.g = function() { Something.onload = function() { "call f" }; }; <- how to refer to function f inside function h?
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:16): i cannot use 'this' in the callback
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:16): since it refers to something's context
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:17): You can us .bind, but you'll need a shim for older browsers
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:17): in java you have similar problem with anonymous inner classes, but you can refer to outer instance using OuterClassName.this
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:18): right, you can do the same InstanceOfMyClass.f() --> this = InstanceOfMyClass
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:18): i tried to use MyClass.prototype.f() but it seems to refer to something else than original instance
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:18): Something.onload = function () { InstanceOfMyClass.f() }
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:19): Are you creating a instance class or static?
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:20): hm, i instance class?
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:20): then instead of calling it using MyClass.prototype.f() you should use the instatiated object's f function, not the prototypes
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:22): hm, i have no idea about that, sec, i try to paste some code
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:22): use jsfiddle to show what you're doing
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:23): http://pastebin.com/D7VqhZHK
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:24): hm, it's plain old javascript, no libraries or anything
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:24): lines 25 and 30 are problematic
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:26): within the search method you can create a variable referencing this, eg: var that = this;
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:27): then within the onload function you can call the addEntry within the right context with that.addEntry(...);
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:27): hm, thought there was another way
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:28): anyway, thanks, seems like it's the only solution
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:28): That is how I normaly do it, if there is a better way, I would like to know :-)
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:30): also, i got eclipse javascript support working, came out i had to enable it manually for the project
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:31): anyway, it asks me to place lot of semicolons
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:31): check your javascript code with JSHint
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:37): hm it outputs lot of errors
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:37): Better start fixing :-)
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:41): ok, two errors are left
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:41): "Use the function form of "use strict"." <- doesn't function form prevent me accessing my classes outside the script?
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:43): http://www.yuiblog.com/blog/2010/12/14/strict-mode-is-coming-to-town/
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:43): so basically i need to wrap my script around large anonymous function?
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:44): it's a good practice, if you look at the source code for most popular 3rd party js code, you'll see that they all do it
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:44): (function (window, undefined) { ...you script here... }) (window);
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:48): hm, my script parts on the .html cannot anymore accept classes from the script file
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:49): if i do not use any 3rd party libs and do not write a lib, i think it should be safe to leave out the function wrapper
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:49): use a global common namespace
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (00:50): hm, how would i assign my class to it?
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:51): Just like you would normally
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:53): you should probably google around a little bit about how to use namespaces and good practices around javascript
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:53): it will answer these questions
7a205621b91e4878465075e964d2b1e8 (00:54): http://na.isobar.com/standards/ this is a good place to start
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (01:09): nice, i wrote my code using module concepts
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (01:10): also eclipse recognizes it
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (01:10): anyway, some parts of code are rather verbose: media.ResultsArea.prototype.clear = function() {
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (01:11): media is the module name, is it possible to make such definitions shorter?
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (01:14): 5b9cb20d2f71fee5f77d39d8e5b3129c: https://github.com/jankuca/dom-panda
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (01:14): appears to be same as the html2canvas approach
5b9cb20d2f71fee5f77d39d8e5b3129c (01:14): yeah, which is pretty odd
5b9cb20d2f71fee5f77d39d8e5b3129c (01:14): this seems exactly like html2canvas
5b9cb20d2f71fee5f77d39d8e5b3129c (01:15): html2canvas takes the DOM and then, given the precomputed properties available from the DOM, draws an image to a canvas
5b9cb20d2f71fee5f77d39d8e5b3129c (01:15): kinda reinventing the wheel
5b9cb20d2f71fee5f77d39d8e5b3129c (01:16): 4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049: though it does look nicer
5b9cb20d2f71fee5f77d39d8e5b3129c (01:16): and oddly it creates it's own NodeWalker O_o
5b9cb20d2f71fee5f77d39d8e5b3129c (01:16): TreeWalker*
5b9cb20d2f71fee5f77d39d8e5b3129c (01:16): which is already available in the DOM
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (01:17): ok, now the second error to go
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (01:19): http://pastebin.com/YiBmazdm <- having two loops with same loop variable
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (01:20): quick fix would be to rename the second loop variable name
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (01:20): but are there another ways?
30713a44e8df7587c64b4dfd1c09d9d2 (01:30): hm, just need to drop var from second loop
